   <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">THE DISCOVERY OF LENSED RADIO AND X-RAY SOURCES BEHIND THE FRONTIER FIELDS CLUSTER MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745 WITH THE JVLA AND <I>CHANDRA</I></h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">R. Mroczkowski</span><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3816-5372\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3816-5372\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 0 256 57.3 256 128z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M86.3 186.2H70.9V79.1h15.4v48.4V186.2z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M108.9 79.1h41.6c39.6 0 57 28.3 57 53.6 0 27.5-21.5 53.6-56.8 53.6h-41.8V79.1zM124.3 172.4h24.5c34.9 0 42.9-26.5 42.9-39.7 0-21.5-13.7-39.7-43.7-39.7h-23.7V172.4z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M88.7 56.8c0 5.5-4.5 10.1-10.1 10.1 -5.6 0-10.1-4.6-10.1-10.1 0-5.6 4.5-10.1 10.1-10.1C84.2 46.7 88.7 51.3 88.7 56.8z\"></path></svg> https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3816-5372</a></span></p><p class=\"mb-05\"><span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">S. S. Murray</span><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6086-0836\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6086-0836\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 0 256 57.3 256 128z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M86.3 186.2H70.9V79.1h15.4v48.4V186.2z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M108.9 79.1h41.6c39.6 0 57 28.3 57 53.6 0 27.5-21.5 53.6-56.8 53.6h-41.8V79.1zM124.3 172.4h24.5c34.9 0 42.9-26.5 42.9-39.7 0-21.5-13.7-39.7-43.7-39.7h-23.7V172.4z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M88.7 56.8c0 5.5-4.5 10.1-10.1 10.1 -5.6 0-10.1-4.6-10.1-10.1 0-5.6 4.5-10.1 10.1-10.1C84.2 46.7 88.7 51.3 88.7 56.8z\"></path></svg> https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6086-0836</a></span></p><p class=\"mb-05\"><span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">S. W. Randall</span><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3984-4337\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3984-4337\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 0 256 57.3 256 128z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M86.3 186.2H70.9V79.1h15.4v48.4V186.2z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M108.9 79.1h41.6c39.6 0 57 28.3 57 53.6 0 27.5-21.5 53.6-56.8 53.6h-41.8V79.1zM124.3 172.4h24.5c34.9 0 42.9-26.5 42.9-39.7 0-21.5-13.7-39.7-43.7-39.7h-23.7V172.4z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M88.7 56.8c0 5.5-4.5 10.1-10.1 10.1 -5.6 0-10.1-4.6-10.1-10.1 0-5.6 4.5-10.1 10.1-10.1C84.2 46.7 88.7 51.3 88.7 56.8z\"></path></svg> https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3984-4337</a></span></p><p class=\"mb-05\"><span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">K. Umetsu</span><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7196-4822\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7196-4822\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 0 256 57.3 256 128z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M86.3 186.2H70.9V79.1h15.4v48.4V186.2z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M108.9 79.1h41.6c39.6 0 57 28.3 57 53.6 0 27.5-21.5 53.6-56.8 53.6h-41.8V79.1zM124.3 172.4h24.5c34.9 0 42.9-26.5 42.9-39.7 0-21.5-13.7-39.7-43.7-39.7h-23.7V172.4z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M88.7 56.8c0 5.5-4.5 10.1-10.1 10.1 -5.6 0-10.1-4.6-10.1-10.1 0-5.6 4.5-10.1 10.1-10.1C84.2 46.7 88.7 51.3 88.7 56.8z\"></path></svg> https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7196-4822</a></span></p><p class=\"mb-05\"><span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">A. Zitrin</span><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0350-4488\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0350-4488\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 individual</a><a                <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F817%2F2%2F98\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/817/2/98</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n            <P>We report on high-resolution <I>JVLA</I> and <I>Chandra</I> observations of the <I>Hubble Space Telescope</I>  (<I>HST</I>) Frontier Cluster MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745. MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745 offers the largest contiguous magnified area of any known cluster, making it a promising target to search for lensed radio and X-ray sources. With the high-resolution 1.0\u20136.5 GHz <I>JVLA</I> imaging in A and B configuration, we detect a total of 51 compact radio sources within the area covered by the <I>HST</I> imaging. Within this sample, we find seven\u00a0lensed sources with amplification factors larger than two. None of these sources are identified as multiply lensed. Based on the radio luminosities, the majority of these sources are likely star-forming galaxies with star-formation rates (SFRs) of 10\u201350 <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/apj522115ieqn1.gif\"></IMG> yr<SUP>\u22121</SUP> located at <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$1\\lesssim z\\lesssim 2$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/apj522115ieqn2.gif\"></IMG>. Two of the lensed radio sources are also detected in the <I>Chandra</I> image of the cluster. These two sources are likely active galactic nuclei, given their 2\u201310 keV X-ray luminosities of ~10<SUP>43\u201344</SUP> erg s<SUP>\u22121</SUP>. From the derived radio luminosity function, we find evidence for an increase in the number density of radio sources at <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.0$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/apj522115ieqn3.gif\"></IMG>, compared to a <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$z\\lt 0.3$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/apj522115ieqn4.gif\"></IMG> sample. Our observations indicate that deep radio imaging of lensing clusters can be used to study star-forming galaxies, with SFRs as low as ~10\u00a0<I>M</I><SUB>\u2299</SUB> yr<SUP>\u22121</SUP>, at the peak of cosmic star formation history.</P></div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/817/2/98&doi=10.3847/0004-637X/817/2/98&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/817/2/98&doi=10.3847/0004-637X/817/2/98&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016ApJ...817...98V\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2016ApJ...817...98V&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2016ApJ...817...98V\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522115s1\" name=\"apj522115s1\">1.\u00a0INTRODUCTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Strong lensing clusters are excellent targets to study high-redshift galaxies due to their large magnification. This offers the advantage of studying these sources at improved spatial resolution and allows the detection of very faint sources due to the amplification of their integrated fluxes (for a review, see Kneib &amp; Natarajan <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib37\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib37\">2011</a>).</p><p>Most blind searches for lensed galaxies behind galaxy clusters have traditionally been carried out at optical, near-infrared (near-IR), and submillimeter wavelengths, with the submillimeter observations mostly targeting rare but very luminous dusty galaxies with high star-formation rates (SFRs). Very few blind and deep studies have been carried out at radio or X-ray wavelengths. One likely reason for this is that the number of lensed active galactic nuclei\u00a0(AGNs) is much lower than that of typical lensed galaxies that are observed at optical and near-IR wavelengths.</p><p>Non-thermal radio emission is also emitted by the more numerous star-forming galaxies, with the radio luminosity correlating with the SFR (e.g., Condon <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib15\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib15\">1992</a>; Bell <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib3\">2003</a>; Garn et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib27\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib27\">2009</a>). Such studies have the advantage of being free from dust extinction. The cosmic SFR increases with redshift, peaking at <em>z</em> ~\u00a02 (for a recent review, see Madau &amp; Dickinson <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib43\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib43\">2014</a>). However, at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn5.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim \\;2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim \\;2</script></span></span>, only the \"tip of the iceberg\" can be currently observed, with extreme SFR of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn6.gif\" alt=\"$\\gtrsim {10}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gtrsim {10}^{2}</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn7.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. A more typical star-forming galaxy, with SFR ~\u00a010\u00a0<em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup> at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn8.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 1.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 1.5</script></span></span>, has an integrated flux density of about one <em>\u03bc</em>Jy at 3 GHz, below the detection limit of the current generation radio telescopes. However, with the power of lensing, these galaxies should come within reach of deep Jansky Very Large Array (<em>JVLA</em>) observations. Combining deep <em>JVLA</em> imaging with lensing will therefore be the only way to study these more typical SF galaxies in the radio at the peak of cosmic SF\u00a0before the advent of the Square Kilometre Array.</p><p>MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745 was discovered by Edge et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib23\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib23\">2003</a>) as part of the MAssive Cluster Survey (MACS; Ebeling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib21\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib21\">2001</a>). It is an extremely massive, hot merging galaxy cluster located at <em>z</em> = 0.5458, with a global temperature of 11.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5 keV (Ebeling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib20\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib20\">2007</a>). A large-scale galaxy filament that is connected to the cluster, with a projected length of ~4.5 Mpc, has also been reported (Ebeling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib19\">2004</a>; Jauzac et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib33\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib33\">2012</a>). The cluster is one of the most complex and dynamically disturbed clusters known, with the merger involving four separate substructures and shock-heated ~20 keV gas (Ma et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib42\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib42\">2008</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib41\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib41\">2009</a>; Limousin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib39\">2012</a>).</p><p>The large total mass of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn9.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{{\\rm{vir}}}=(3.5\\pm 0.6)\\times {10}^{15}\\;{M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{{\\rm{vir}}}=(3.5\\pm 0.6)\\times {10}^{15}\\;{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> (Umetsu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib60\">2014</a>) and relatively shallow mass profile of the cluster boosts the gravitational lens magnification and results in a total lensed area that is about 3.5 arcmin<sup>2</sup> for a galaxy located at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn10.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 8$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 8</script></span></span>. This area is higher than any other known massive cluster (Zitrin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib63\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib63\">2009a</a>). For this reason, the cluster is also part of the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble (CLASH; Postman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib52\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib52\">2012</a>; Medezinski et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib45\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib45\">2013</a>) and the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em>  (<em>HST</em>) Frontier Fields program.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj522115fn5\">21</a></sup>\n\n</p><p>Since MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745 is the largest known cosmic lens, it is a prime target to search for radio and X-ray emission associated with lensed background galaxies. In this work, we present deep high-resolution <em>JVLA</em> observations which can be used for this purpose. In addition, we carry out a search for lensed X-ray sources with newly acquired deep <em>Chandra</em> data. We adopt a \u039bCDM cosmology with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"${H}_{{\\rm{0}}}=70$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{H}_{{\\rm{0}}}=70</script></span></span> km s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{m}}}=0.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{m}}}=0.3</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7</script></span></span>. With this cosmology, 1'' corresponds to a physical scale of 6.387\u00a0kpc at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.5458.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522115s2\" name=\"apj522115s2\">2.\u00a0OBSERVATIONS AND DATA REDUCTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj522115s2-1\" name=\"apj522115s2-1\">2.1.\u00a0JVLA Observations</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p><em>JVLA</em> observations of MACS\u00a0J07175+3745 were obtained in the L-band (1\u20132 GHz) in the A-array configuration, in the S-band (2\u20134 GHz) in the A- and B-array configurations, and in the C-band (4.5\u20136.5 GHz) in the B-array configuration. All observations were done using single 6\u00a0hr runs, resulting in a typical on-source time of ~5\u00a0hr. The total recorded bandwidth was 1 GHz for the L-band, and 2 GHz for the S- and C-bands. The primary calibrators were 3C138 and 3C147. The secondary calibrator (J0713+4349) was observed for a couple of minutes at 30\u201340\u00a0minute intervals. All four circular polarization products were recorded. An overview of the observations is given in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t1\">1</a>.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj522115t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0\nJVLA Observations\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522115t1\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t1_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 1\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\u00a0</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">L-band A-array</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">S-band A-array</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">S-band B-array</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">C-band B-array</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Observation dates</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2013 Mar 28</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2013 Feb 22</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2013 Nov 5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2013 Sep 30</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Frequencies coverage (GHz)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1\u20132</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2\u20134</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2\u20134</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">4.5\u20136.5</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">On source time (hr)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">~5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">~5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">~5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">~5</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Correlations</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">full stokes</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">full stokes</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">full stokes</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">full stokes</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Channel width (MHz)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Integration time (s)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">3</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">LAS (arcsec)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">36</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">18</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">58</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">29</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t1_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/0004-637X/817/2/98\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>The data were reduced with <tt>CASA</tt> version 4.2.1 (McMullin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib44\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib44\">2007</a>). The data from the different observing runs were all reduced in the same way. For the two primary calibrators, we used the clean-component models provided by CASA. We also took the overall spectral index of the primary calibrator sources into account, scaling the flux density for each channel.</p><p>As a first step, the data were Hanning smoothed and pre-determined elevation-dependent gain tables and antenna position offsets were applied. This was followed by automatic flagging of radio frequency interference (RFI) using the <em>tfcrop</em> mode of the <tt>CASA</tt> task <tt>flagdata</tt>. We then determined an initial bandpass correction using 3C147. This bandpass was applied and additional RFI was identified and flagged with the <tt>AOFlagger</tt> (Offringa et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib49\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib49\">2010</a>). The reason for applying the bandpass is to avoid flagging good data due to the bandpass roll off at the edges of the spectral windows.</p><p>Next, we determined complex gain solutions on 3C147 for the central 10 channels of each spectral window to remove possible time variations of the gains during the calibrator observations. We pre-applied these solutions to find the delay terms (<tt>gaintype =</tt> \"<tt>K</tt>\") and bandpass calibration. Applying the bandpass and delay solutions, we re-determined the complex gain solutions for both primary calibrators using the full bandwidth. We then determined the global cross-hand delay solutions (<tt>gaintype =</tt> \"<tt>KCROSS</tt>\") from the polarized calibrator 3C138. For 3C138, we assumed a rotation measure (RM) of 0\u00a0rad\u00a0m<sup>\u22121</sup>, and for the RL-phase difference we took \u221215\u00b0. All relevant solutions tables were applied on the fly to determine the complex gain solution for the secondary calibrator J0713+4349 and to establish its flux density scale accordingly. The absolute flux scale uncertainty due to bootstrapping from the calibrators is assumed to be a few percent (Perley &amp; Butler <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib51\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib51\">2013</a>). As a next step, we used J0713+4349 to find the channel-dependent polarization leakage terms. 3C138 was used to perform the polarization angle calibration for each channel.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj522115fn6\">22</a></sup>\n Finally, all solutions were applied to the target field. The corrected data were then averaged by a factor of 3 in time and a factor of 6 in frequency.</p><p>To refine the calibration for the target field, we performed three rounds of phase-only self-calibration and a final round of amplitude and phase self-calibration. For the imaging we employed w-projection (Cornwell et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib18\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib18\">2008</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib17\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib17\">2005</a>) to take the non-coplanar nature of the array into account. Image sizes of up to 12288<sup>2</sup> pixels were needed (A-array configuration) to deconvolve a few bright sources outside the main lobe of the primary beam. For each frequency band, the full bandwidth was used to make a single deep Stokes I continuum image. We used Briggs (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib12\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib12\">1995</a>) weighting with a robust factor of 0. The spectral index was taken into account during the deconvolution of each observing run (<tt>nterms = 3</tt>; Rau &amp; Cornwell <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib53\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib53\">2011</a>). We manually flagged some additional data during the self-calibration process by visually inspecting the self-calibration solutions. Clean masks were employed during the deconvolution. The clean masks were made with the <tt>PyBDSM</tt> source detection package (Mohan &amp; Rafferty <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib47\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib47\">2015</a>). The S-band A-array and B-array configuration data were combined after the self-calibration to make a single deep 2\u20134 GHz image. The final images were made with Briggs weighting and a robust factor of 0.75, except for the C-band image, for which we employed natural weighting. Images were corrected for the primary beam attenuation, with the frequency dependence of the beam taken into account. An overview of the resulting image properties, such as rms noise and resolution, is given in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t2\">2</a>.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj522115t2\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 2.</b>\u00a0\nImage Properties\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522115t2\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t2_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 2\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\u00a0</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">L-band A-array</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">S-band A+B-array</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">C-band B-array</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Resolution (arcsec\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a0arcsec)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.5\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a01.3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.04\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a00.79</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.80\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a01.38</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Noise (<em>\u03bc</em>Jy beam<sup>\u22121</sup>)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">5.2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.8</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.9</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t2_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/0004-637X/817/2/98\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t2_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apj522115s2-2\" name=\"apj522115s2-2\">2.2.\u00a0Chandra Observations</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745 was observed with <em>Chandra</em> for a total of 243 ks between 2001 and 2013. A summary of the observations is presented in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t3\">3</a>. The data sets were reduced with CIAO v4.7 and CALDB v4.6.5, following the same methodology that was described by Ogrean et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib50\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib50\">2015</a>).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj522115t3\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 3.</b>\u00a0\nSummary of the <em>Chandra</em> Observations\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522115t3\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t3_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 3\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">ObsID</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Instrument</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Mode</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Start Date</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Exposure Time (ks)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Filtered Exposure Time (ks)</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">1655</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">ACIS-I</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">FAINT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2001 Jan 29</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">19.87</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">17.06</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">4200</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">ACIS-I</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">VFAINT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2004 Jan 10</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">59.04</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">58.02</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">16235</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">ACIS-I</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">FAINT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2013 Dec 16</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">70.16</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">68.37</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">16305</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">ACIS-I</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">VFAINT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2013 Dec 11</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">94.34</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">90.42</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t3_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/0004-637X/817/2/98\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t3_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Point sources were detected with the CIAO script <em>wavdetect</em> in the energy bands 0.5\u20132 and 2\u20137 keV, using wavelet scales of 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32 pixels and ellipses with radii <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"$5\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">5\\sigma</script></span></span> around the centers of the detected sources. Due to the complicated morphology of MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745, all sources found by <em>wavdetect</em> were visually inspected and some false detections associated with the extended ICM of the cluster were removed. The local background around each point source was described using an elliptical annulus with an inner radius equal to the source radius and an outer radius approximately ~3\u00a0times larger than the source radius. To model the X-ray spectra of the point sources, the local background spectra were subtracted from the corresponding source spectra. The spectra were binned to a minimum of one\u00a0count/bin, and modeled with <span class=\"small-caps\">Xspec</span>\u00a0v12.8.2 using the extended C-statistics<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj522115fn7\">23</a></sup>\n (Cash <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib14\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib14\">1979</a>; Wachter et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib61\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib61\">1979</a>). All the source spectra were modeled as power\u00a0laws and included galactic absorption. The hydrogen column density in the direction of MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745 was fixed to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn15.gif\" alt=\"$8.4\\times {10}^{20}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">8.4\\times {10}^{20}</script></span></span> cm<sup>\u22122</sup>, which is the sum of the weighted average atomic hydrogen column density from the Leiden\u2013Argentine\u2013Bonn (LAB; Kalberla et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib36\">2005</a>) Survey and the molecular hydrogen column density determined by Willingale et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib62\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib62\">2013</a>) from <em>Swift</em> data.</p><p>X-ray fluxes and luminosities were calculated in the energy band 2\u201310 keV, with uncertainties quoted at the 90% confidence level.</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522115s3\" name=\"apj522115s3\">3.\u00a0RESULTS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The 2\u20134 GHz S-band image of the cluster region is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522115f1\">1</a>. The most prominent source in the images is a large filamentary radio relic that is associated with the cluster MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745. At the center of this relic, a narrow angle tail (NAT) galaxy is visible, which is associated with a cluster member at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.5528 (Ebeling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib22\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib22\">2014</a>). Another tailed radio source (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.5399;\u00a0Ebeling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib22\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib22\">2014</a>) is visible at the far SE corner of the image. A bright linearly shaped FRI-type radio source (Fanaroff &amp; Riley <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib26\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib26\">1974</a>) is located to the SE. This source is associated with an elliptical foreground galaxy (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"cite object-linking\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/relatedobj?objId=2MASX+J07173724%3D3744224&amp;directLookup=true\">2MASX J07173724+3744224</a>) located at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.1546 (Bonafede et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib9\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib9\">2009</a>). The radio relics and tailed radio galaxies belonging to MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745 will be discussed in a separate paper (R. J. van Weeren et al. 2015, in preparation).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522115f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522115f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0S-band B+A-array image made with robust = 0.75 weighting (Briggs <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib12\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib12\">1995</a>). The image has a resolution of 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8 and a noise level of 1.8\u00a0<em>\u03bc</em>Jy beam<sup>\u22121</sup>. Compact radio and X-ray sources that fall within the <em>HST</em> coverage are indicated. Blue circles represent objects for which we could confirm that they are located behind the cluster. Blue double circled sources have amplification factors <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn16.gif\" alt=\"$\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gt 2</script></span></span> and are individually discussed in Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522115s3-2\">3.2</a>. Red circles represent cluster and foreground radio sources. Light blue circled sources have too uncertain redshifts to determine if they are cluster members, foreground objects, or background objects. Boxes indicate X-ray-detected sources, with\u00a0color coding\u00a0identical to the radio sources. Black contours show the X-ray emission from <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn17.gif\" alt=\"${\\text{}}{\\text{}}{Chandra}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\text{}}{\\text{}}{Chandra}</script></span></span> smoothed with a Gaussian with a FWHM of 10''. X-ray contours are drawn at levels of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn18.gif\" alt=\"$[5,20,50]\\times $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">[5,20,50]\\times</script></span></span> the background level (determined by measuring the background level around 2.5 Mpc, i.e., <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sime.gif\" alt=\"sime\" align=\"baseline\" /><em>R</em><sub>200</sub>) from the cluster center. Both sky and instrumental background were included here.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522115f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadFigure/figure/apj522115f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522115f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522115f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><h3 id=\"apj522115s3-1\" name=\"apj522115s3-1\">3.1.\u00a0Source Detection</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We used the <tt>PyBDSM</tt>\n<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj522115fn8\">24</a></sup>\n source detection package to find and determine the integrated flux densities of the radio sources in the images. <tt>PyBDSM</tt> identifies \"islands\" of contiguous pixels above a detection threshold and fits each island with Gaussians.</p><p>For detecting these islands, we took a threshold of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn19.gif\" alt=\"$3{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">3{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}</script></span></span> and a pixel threshold of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn20.gif\" alt=\"$4{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}</script></span></span>, meaning that at least one pixel in each island needs to exceed the local background by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn21.gif\" alt=\"$4{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}</script></span></span>. We determined the local rms noise using a sliding box with a size of 300 pixels to take the noise increase by the primary beam attenuation into account. We manually inspected the output source catalogs and removed any source associated with the radio relic and foreground FR-I source since these sources are larger than the 300\u00a0pixel box size for the local noise determination. The source detection was run on all three frequency maps. The locations of the detected sources are indicated on Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522115f1\">1</a>.</p><p>We then searched for optical counterparts to the radio sources within the area covered by the <em>HST</em> CLASH catalog and <em>HST</em> Frontier Fields observations. For the detected radio sources, we overlaid the radio contours on an\u00a0<em>HST</em> Frontier Fields color (v1.0<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj522115fn9\">25</a></sup>\n, F425W, F606W, and F814W band) image to verify that the correct counterparts were identified;\u00a0see Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522115f2\">2</a> (lensed sources) and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522115f5\">5</a>. Counterparts were found for all radio sources. In a few cases, more than one optical counterpart was identified for the radio source in the CLASH catalog because of the complex morphology of the galaxy in the <em>HST</em> images. An overview of all the compact lensed radio sources that were found within the <em>HST</em> FOV is given in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t4\">4</a>. The properties of the sources that are not lensed, or for which we could not determine if they were located behind the cluster, are listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t5\">5</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522115f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522115f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115f2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115f2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0<em>HST</em> F435, F606W, and F814W postage stamp color images of the compact lensed radio sources in the MACS\u00a0J0717.3745 field. Similar postage stamp images, but for sources that are not lensed, are shown in Figure <a href=\"#apj522115f5\">5</a>. The red radio contours are from the 2\u20134 GHz S-band image and drawn at levels <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn22.gif\" alt=\"$\\sqrt{([1,2,4,\\ldots ])}\\times 3{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sqrt{([1,2,4,\\ldots ])}\\times 3{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}</script></span></span>, with <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn23.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}=1.8$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}=1.8</script></span></span> <em>\u03bc</em>Jy beam<sup>\u22121</sup>. The beam size is indicated in the bottom left corner. We draw white radio contours for some images to aid visibility (in case the area was not covered by all the <em>HST</em> filters). For sources without an S-band detection, we overlay contours from the C-band image (if detected there) or the L-band image. We use contours from the combined L-, S-, and C-band images if the source is not detected in any of the three individual band images. The values for <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn24.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}</script></span></span> for the L- and C-band images are listed in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t2\">2</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522115f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadFigure/figure/apj522115f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522115f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522115f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj522115t4\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 4.</b>\u00a0\nProperties of Cluster Background Sources\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522115t4\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t4_lr.gif\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong> The source ID and positions are taken from the CLASH catalog. The photometric redshifts (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn60.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}</script></span></span>) and best fitting spectral template (<em>t</em><sub><em>b</em></sub>) are also taken from the CLASH catalog. The photometric redshifts are given at a 95% confidence level. The spectral templates are described in Molino et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib48\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib48\">2014</a>). In total, there are 11 possible spectral templates, 5\u00a0for elliptical galaxies (1\u20135), 2\u00a0for spiral galaxies (6, 7), and 4\u00a0for starburst galaxies (8\u201311), along with emission lines and dust extinction. Non-integer values indicate interpolated templates between adjacent templates. For the radio flux density errors, we include a 2.5% uncertainty from bootstrapping the flux density scale. The listed amplification factors are the mean values from the models: <tt>CATS</tt>_<tt>v1</tt> (Jauzac et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib33\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib33\">2012</a>; Richard et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib56\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib56\">2014</a>), <tt>Sharon</tt>_<tt>v2</tt> (Johnson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib34\">2014</a>), <tt>Zitrin-ltm</tt>_<tt>v1</tt>, <tt>Zitrin-ltm-Gauss</tt>_<tt>v1</tt> (e.g., Zitrin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib65\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib65\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib64\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib64\">2009b</a>), <tt>GLAFIC</tt>_<tt>v3</tt> (Ishigaki et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib29\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib29\">2015</a>), <tt>Williams</tt>_<tt>v1</tt> (e.g., Liesenborgs et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib38\">2006</a>), <tt>Bradac</tt>_<tt>v1</tt> (Brada\u010d et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib10\">2005</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib11\">2009</a>), <tt>Merten</tt>_<tt>v1</tt> (e.g., Merten et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib46\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib46\">2011</a>). For the spectroscopic redshifts (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn62.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{spec}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{spec}}}</script></span></span>), the spectral classification is as follows: A\u2014absorption-line spectrum; E\u2014emission-line spectrum.</p>\n<a name=\"apj522115fn10\" id=\"apj522115fn10\"></a><sup> a</sup>Manually measured.\n<a name=\"apj522115fn11\" id=\"apj522115fn11\"></a><sup> b</sup>Flux density measurement could be affected by radio emission from other sources.\n<a name=\"apj522115fn12\" id=\"apj522115fn12\"></a><sup> c</sup>Very faint source, only peak flux was measured.\n<a name=\"apj522115fn13\" id=\"apj522115fn13\"></a><sup> d</sup>The complex morphology of the galaxy likely caused it to be fragmented and listed as separate objects in the catalog.\n<a name=\"apj522115fn14\" id=\"apj522115fn14\"></a><sup> e</sup>We assume that these source components have the same redshift as S24<sub>3</sub>.\n<a name=\"apj522115fn15\" id=\"apj522115fn15\"></a><sup> f</sup>We assume that this source component has the same redshift as S61<sub>1</sub>.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn align=\"center\">6.30</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.5660\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0003 (E)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">S49 7693</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">109.3710599</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">X64<sub>2</sub><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115fn19\"><sup>d</sup></a> 2222</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">109.4095458</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">37.7711695</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"right\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\"
