type=\"math/tex\">{0.8}_{-0.5}^{+2.4}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">8.00</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn125.gif\" alt=\"${6.20}_{-4.71}^{+3.09}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{6.20}_{-4.71}^{+3.09}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">X64<sub>2</sub><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115fn19\"><sup>d</sup></a> 2222</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">109.4095458</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">37.7711695</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"right\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn126.gif\" alt=\"${0.6}_{-0.2}^{+3.1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.6}_{-0.2}^{+3.1}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">8.70</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn127.gif\" alt=\"${6.20}_{-4.71}^{+3.09}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{6.20}_{-4.71}^{+3.09}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong> The source ID and positions are taken from the CLASH catalog. The photometric redshifts (<em>z</em><sub>phot</sub>) and best fitting spectral template (<em>t</em><sub><em>b</em></sub>) are also taken from the CLASH catalog. The photometric redshifts are given at a 95% confidence level. The spectral templates are described in Molino et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib48\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib48\">2014</a>). In total, there are 11 possible spectral templates, 5\u00a0for elliptical galaxies (1\u20135), 2\u00a0for spiral galaxies (6, 7), and 4\u00a0for starburst galaxies (8\u201311), along with emission lines and dust extinction. Non-integer values indicate interpolated templates between adjacent templates. For the radio flux density errors, we include a 2.5% uncertainty from bootstrapping the flux density scale. For the spectroscopic redshifts (<em>z</em><sub>spec</sub>), the spectral classification is as follows: A\u2014absorption-line spectrum; E\u2014emission-line spectrum.</p>\n<a name=\"apj522115fn16\" id=\"apj522115fn16\"></a><sup> a</sup>Manually measured.\n<a name=\"apj522115fn17\" id=\"apj522115fn17\"></a><sup> b</sup>Flux density measurement could be affected by radio emission from other sources.\n<a name=\"apj522115fn18\" id=\"apj522115fn18\"></a><sup> c</sup>Very faint source, only peak flux was measured.\n<a name=\"apj522115fn19\" id=\"apj522115fn19\"></a><sup> d</sup>The complex morphology of the galaxy likely caused it to be fragmented and listed as separate objects in the catalog.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t5_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/0004-637X/817/2/98\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/suppdata/apj522115t5_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>To detect even fainter radio sources, we combined the individual L-, S-, and C-band images into one deep 1\u20136.5 GHz wideband continuum image, scaling with a spectral index<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj522115fn20\">26</a></sup>\n (<em>\u03b1</em>) of \u22120.5. This was done by convolving all maps to the resolution of the C-band image. With the help of this deep image, we identified about a dozen more sources below the <tt>PyBDSM</tt> detection threshold in the individual maps, but with peak fluxes above the local <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn131.gif\" alt=\"$3{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">3{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}</script></span></span>. We manually determined the flux densities of these sources in <tt>AIPS</tt> with the task <tt>JMFIT</tt>. In addition, we visually identified five more sources in this deep image that were below the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn132.gif\" alt=\"$3{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">3{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}</script></span></span> thresholds in the individual maps and thus not recognized there. These sources are also listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t4\">4</a> (and Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t5\">5</a>). We do not report integrated flux densities for these sources since they are not clearly detected in any of the individual maps. The CLASH photometric redshift and best fitting BPZ (Ben\u00edtez <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib4\">2000</a>) spectral template for each source are also listed. For more details on the photometric redshifts and spectral templates, the reader is referred to Molino et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib48\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib48\">2014</a>) and Jouvel et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib35\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib35\">2014</a>). For 23 sources, spectroscopic redshifts are available from Ebeling et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib22\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib22\">2014</a>).</p><p>For the sources that are located at redshifts larger than the cluster, we include the amplification factors in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t4\">4</a>, taking the average over all the eight\u00a0publicly available<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj522115fn21\">27</a></sup>\n <em>HST</em> Frontier Fields lensing models for MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745. The amplifications at a given redshift are calculated directly from the mass (<em>\u03ba</em>) and shear (<em>\u03b3</em>) maps. For more details on how these lensing models were derived, we refer to reader to the references provided in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t4\">4</a>. The reported uncertainties in the amplification factors for the individual models are smaller than the scatter between these models. Therefore, for the uncertainty in the amplification factor, we take the standard deviation between these models, which should better reflect the actual uncertainties.</p><p>In total, we find 51 compact radio sources within the area covered by the <em>HST</em> imaging. In this sample, 16 sources are located behind the cluster, i.e., those where the 95% confidence limit of the lower redshift bound places it beyond the cluster redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.5458. Of these sources, seven\u00a0have amplification factors larger than 2. We plot the location of the lensed radio and X-ray sources on top of an amplification map for a <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02 source in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522115f3\">3</a>. We used the <tt>Zitrin-ltm-Gauss</tt>_<tt>v1</tt> model amplification map as an example here. We discuss these lensed sources with amplification factors larger than 2 in some more detail in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522115s3-2\">3.2</a>. About a dozen radio sources are associated with cluster members (i.e., <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn133.gif\" alt=\"$0.5\\lt {z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}\\lt 0.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.5\\lt {z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}\\lt 0.6</script></span></span>).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522115f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522115f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0Amplification/magnification map for a <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02 source from the <tt>Zitrin-ltm-Gauss</tt>_<tt>v1</tt> lensing model. For details of the lens modeling, see\u00a0Zitrin et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib64\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib64\">2009b</a>). The location of the background compact sources are indicated as in Figure <a href=\"#apj522115f1\">1</a>. Black contours show the X-ray emission from <em>Chandra</em>, smoothed with a Gaussian with a FWHM of 10''. X-ray contours are drawn at levels of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn134.gif\" alt=\"$[5,20,50]\\times $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">[5,20,50]\\times</script></span></span> the X-ray background level as in Figure <a href=\"#apj522115f1\">1</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522115f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadFigure/figure/apj522115f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522115f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522115f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We also search for the presence of compact X-ray sources within the <em>HST</em> FOV. In total, we detect seven\u00a0X-ray sources. Five of these have radio counterparts. The X-ray sources are also included in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t4\">4</a>, with the measured X-ray fluxes. Two of these X-ray sources which have radio counterparts\u00a0are lensed by the cluster. The other X-ray sources are foreground objects, cluster members, or have uncertain redshifts.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522115s3-2\" name=\"apj522115s3-2\">3.2.\u00a0Lensed Sources</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>In this section, we discuss the radio and X-ray properties of the lensed sources with amplification factors <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn135.gif\" alt=\"$\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gt 2</script></span></span>. These sources are double circled in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522115f1\">1</a>. For the sources that are not obvious AGNs\u00a0(i.e., those that do not have X-ray counterparts), we compute the star-formation rate based on the measured radio luminosity. When converting from flux density to luminosity, we used the amplification factors listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t4\">4</a>. The radio luminosity of the galaxies (non-AGN) can be converted to mean star-formation rate over the past <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn136.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim {10}^{8}\\;{\\rm{years}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim {10}^{8}\\;{\\rm{years}}</script></span></span> (Best et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib8\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib8\">2002</a>) using</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj522115eqn1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115eqn1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\rm{SFR}}}{{M}_{\\odot }\\;{{\\rm{yr}}}^{-1}}\\approx 4.5{\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\rm{GHz}}}{\\nu }\\right)}^{\\alpha }\\displaystyle \\frac{{L}_{\\nu }}{{10}^{22}\\;{\\rm{W}}\\ {{\\rm{Hz}}}^{-1}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>L</em><sub><em>\u03bd</em></sub> represents the k-corrected rest-frame radio luminosity (which is also corrected for the amplification). The underlying assumptions are that cosmic rays from SNe II trace star-forming regions and that the number of SNe II is directly proportional to the SFR. An advantage of these radio-derived SFRs is that they are not significantly affected by dust extinction. For our sources, we use the 3 GHz measurement (unless stated otherwise), scaling with a spectral index of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn137.gif\" alt=\"$\\alpha =-0.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\alpha =-0.5</script></span></span>. The uncertainty in the radio-derived SFR is about a factor of 2 (Bell <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib3\">2003</a>).</p><p>We can also compute the specific SFRs (sSFR) by computing the stellar mass (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn138.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\star }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\star }</script></span></span>) from the <em>Spitzer</em>  3.6 and 4.5 <em>\u03bc</em>m fluxes, following the approach by Rawle et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib54\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib54\">2014</a>). We corrected these fluxes for the amplification and computed the K-correction using the BPZ spectral templates. The <em>Spitzer</em>  fluxes are taken from SEIP Source List (Enhanced Imaging Products from the <em>Spitzer</em>  Heritage Archive;\u00a0we took the 3<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8 diameter aperture flux densities). To compute the stellar mass, we use the relation from Eskew et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib25\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib25\">2012</a>)</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj522115eqn2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115eqn2.gif\" alt=\"Equation (2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{M}_{*}[{M}_{\\odot }]={10}^{5.65}{S}_{3.6\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}}^{2.85}{S}_{4.5\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}}^{-1.85}{({D}_{{\\rm{L}}}/0.05)}^{2}{\\rm{}}\\;,\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>S</em><sub><em>\u03bb</em></sub> is in units of Jy, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn139.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{{\\rm{L}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{{\\rm{L}}}</script></span></span> the luminosity distance in megaparsecs. This relation was derived for the Large Magellanic Cloud and assumes a Salpeter (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib57\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib57\">1955</a>) initial mass function (IMF). It may break down for more strongly star-forming systems and might also vary with metallicity. Therefore, Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj522115eqn2\">2</a>) should be taken as an approximation to the stellar mass.</p><h4 id=\"apj522115s3-2-1\" name=\"apj522115s3-2-1\">3.2.1.\u00a0Comments on Individual Sources</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The source S0 has a spectroscopically measured redshift of 1.6852\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.001 (Ebeling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib22\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib22\">2014</a>) and an amplification factor of 3.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.0 The source is associated with a disk galaxy that has a central bright core in the <em>HST</em> image. The source is also detected with <em>Chandra</em> (171 \u00b1 25 net counts) with an unabsorbed 2\u201310 keV flux of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn140.gif\" alt=\"${1.71}_{-0.20}^{+0.16}\\times {10}^{-14}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{1.71}_{-0.20}^{+0.16}\\times {10}^{-14}</script></span></span> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup> cm<sup>\u22122</sup>. The photon index of the power\u00a0law of was determined at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn141.gif\" alt=\"${0.89}_{-0.42}^{+0.33}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.89}_{-0.42}^{+0.33}</script></span></span>. Together with the amplification factor and associated uncertainty, this translates into a rest-frame luminosity of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn142.gif\" alt=\"${0.29}_{-0.07}^{+0.11}\\times {10}^{44}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.29}_{-0.07}^{+0.11}\\times {10}^{44}</script></span></span> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, typical of an AGN. The optical spectrum of the galaxy contains emission lines and the best fitting BPZ template is that of an Sbc-type spiral galaxy.</p><p>Source S6 seems to be associated with a compact star-like object. We also find an X-ray counterpart to the source (150 \u00b1 12 net counts). The object has a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn143.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}={1.89}_{-0.09}^{+0.08}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}={1.89}_{-0.09}^{+0.08}</script></span></span> and an amplification factor of 2.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7. With this amplification factor and redshift, the unabsorbed 2\u201310 keV flux of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn144.gif\" alt=\"${8.48}_{-1.08}^{+1.24}\\times {10}^{-15}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{8.48}_{-1.08}^{+1.24}\\times {10}^{-15}</script></span></span> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup> cm<sup>\u22122</sup> translates to a rest-frame luminosity of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn145.gif\" alt=\"${0.88}_{-0.25}^{+0.41}\\times {10}^{44}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.88}_{-0.25}^{+0.41}\\times {10}^{44}</script></span></span> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The photon index of the power law of was determined at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn146.gif\" alt=\"${2.05}_{-0.23}^{+0.24}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{2.05}_{-0.23}^{+0.24}</script></span></span>. The best fitting BPZ template was that of a spiral galaxy, but the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn147.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }^{2}</script></span></span> value of 29.3 indicated a very poor fit. Given the star-like nature of the object and poor fit, this source could be a quasar.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj522115fn22\">28</a></sup>\n\n</p><p>S8 is located at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn148.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}={1.15}_{-0.03}^{+0.04}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}={1.15}_{-0.03}^{+0.04}</script></span></span> and has a high amplification factor of about 6.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.8. The best fitting BPZ template is that of a starburst galaxy. Based on the S-band radio flux, we compute a SFR of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn149.gif\" alt=\"${15}_{-7}^{+12}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{15}_{-7}^{+12}</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn150.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. With <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn151.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{*}={2.4}_{-1.0}^{+1.4}\\times {10}^{10}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{*}={2.4}_{-1.0}^{+1.4}\\times {10}^{10}</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn152.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> we compute a sSFR of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn153.gif\" alt=\"${0.6}_{-0.3}^{+0.4}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.6}_{-0.3}^{+0.4}</script></span></span> Gyr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The errors take into account the uncertainties in the radio and <em>Spitzer</em>  flux density measurements, amplification factor (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t4\">4</a>), and redshift. For the radio spectral index, we assumed an uncertainty of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn154.gif\" alt=\"${\\rm{\\Delta }}\\alpha =0.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\rm{\\Delta }}\\alpha =0.3</script></span></span>. Errors where estimated via a Monte Carlo approach, drawing 10<sup>4</sup> realizations. Note that <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn155.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{*}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{*}</script></span></span>, SFR, and sSFR are computed under the assumption that Equations (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj522115eqn1\">1</a>) and (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj522115eqn2\">2</a>) hold.</p><p>S9 is associated with a faint red galaxy with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn156.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}={1.69}_{-0.06}^{+0.22}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}={1.69}_{-0.06}^{+0.22}</script></span></span> and is amplified with a factor of 3.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.0. The best fitting BPZ template corresponds to a Sbc/ES0 galaxy. The source has a relatively flat spectral index of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn157.gif\" alt=\"$\\alpha =-0.4\\pm 0.2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\alpha =-0.4\\pm 0.2</script></span></span> between 1.5 and 5.5 GHz. Based on the integrated flux density, we compute a high SFR of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn158.gif\" alt=\"${49}_{-21}^{+46}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{49}_{-21}^{+46}</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn159.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, scaling with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn160.gif\" alt=\"$\\alpha =-0.4.$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\alpha =-0.4.</script></span></span> A blue galaxy is located about 1'' to the east of this galaxy at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn161.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{photo}}}={1.70}_{-0.14}^{+0.12}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{photo}}}={1.70}_{-0.14}^{+0.12}</script></span></span>. With <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn162.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{*}={4.5}_{-1.9}^{+3.3}\\times {10}^{10}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{*}={4.5}_{-1.9}^{+3.3}\\times {10}^{10}</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn163.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> we compute a sSFR of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn164.gif\" alt=\"${1.1}_{-0.5}^{+0.8}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{1.1}_{-0.5}^{+0.8}</script></span></span> Gyr<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p>S45 is associated with a faint red galaxy with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn165.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}\\ ={1.41}_{-0.19}^{+0.06}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{phot}}}\\ ={1.41}_{-0.19}^{+0.06}</script></span></span>. It has a high amplification factor of 8.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04.1 with a best fitting spiral galaxy spectral template. We compute a SFR of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn166.gif\" alt=\"${17}_{-11}^{+29}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{17}_{-11}^{+29}</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn167.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p>In addition to the above sources that were detected in the individual L-, S-, or C-band images, we also found two sources in the deep broad-band stacked radio image with amplifications <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn168.gif\" alt=\"$\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gt 2</script></span></span>. S48 is associated with a red galaxy at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn169.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{photo}}}={0.91}_{-0.06}^{+0.07}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{photo}}}={0.91}_{-0.06}^{+0.07}</script></span></span>, with an amplification factor that is slightly less than 3. It is best fit by a spiral BPZ template. S61 is associated with a blue irregular galaxy. Its amplification factor is 3.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.5 and the best fitting spectral template is that of a starburst galaxy. It is listed as two separate objects in the CLASH photometric catalog, with component 2 (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t4\">4</a>) being a bright \"knot\" to the north, embedded within the overall emission from the galaxy (component 1). Thus, the <em>HST</em> images suggest that both components belong the same galaxy with a complex morphology. This is also consistent with the two photometric redshifts that indicate <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn170.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{photo}}}\\approx 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{photo}}}\\approx 1.6</script></span></span>.</p><p>It should be acknowledged that some of the sources we identify here, particularly those that lay behind the cluster according to their photometric redshifts, may be multiple images of multiply lensed background sources. A brief search according to the predictions of the model seen in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522115f3\">3</a> neither assigned sources listed here to the same multiply imaged sources, nor were other counter images located. We also cross-checked the position of our lensed sources against the list of multiply lensed sources by Limousin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib39\">2012</a>), but none of our sources appear in this list. This means that\u2014adopting the lens model in hand\u2014either the photometric redshift for these images significantly deviate than those listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t4\">4</a>, or that the predicted counter images's flux is below the detection limit given a possibly smaller magnification, for example. A more dedicated examination and search for multiple images among our sample will be performed elsewhere.</p></div></div><h3 id=\"apj522115s3-3\" name=\"apj522115s3-3\">3.3.\u00a0Radio Luminosity Function</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>It is expected that the number of star-forming galaxies increases with redshift, peaking at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn171.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> (e.g., Madau &amp; Dickinson <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib43\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib43\">2014</a>). We compute the radio luminosity function from the sources detected in our S-band image that have a 3 GHz flux density above 18\u00a0<em>\u03bc</em>Jy (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn172.gif\" alt=\"$10\\times {\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">10\\times {\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}</script></span></span>). Above this flux density, we should be reasonably complete\u00a0also for sources that are resolved.</p><p>For the luminosity function, we determine the volume behind the cluster in which we could detect a hypothetical source above the flux limit for a given luminosity. We then divide the number of detected sources (for that luminosity range) by the obtained volume. To compute the volume, we take the varying magnification (as a function of position and redshift) into account using the publicly available lensing models and provided <tt>Python</tt> code.</p><p>We excluded the regions covered by the radio relic. We scaled our 3 GHz S-band luminosities to 1.4 GHz taking <em>\u03b1</em> = \u22120.5, to facilitate a comparison with the literature results from Best et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib6\">2005</a>). We limited ourselves to the range <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn173.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.0</script></span></span>, because we only detect a single source above <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn174.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>. Restricting the redshift range also limits the effects of the redshift evolution of the radio luminosity function.</p><p>The differences between the lensing models are larger than the uncertainties provided for the individual models. We therefore compute the volume for each for the eight\u00a0models listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t4\">4</a> and take the average. The same is done for counting the number of sources in each luminosity bin (as this also depends on the amplification factors). In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522115f4\">4</a> we plot the luminosity function averaged over these eight\u00a0different lensing models. The red error bars represent the standard deviation over the eight\u00a0lensing models. The black error bars show the combined uncertainty from the lensing models and Poisson errors on the galaxy number counts. These two errors were added in quadrature. We find that the uncertainties in the redshifts and flux density measurements do not contribute significantly to the error budget.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522115f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522115f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Radio luminosity function (number density of sources) at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn175.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.0</script></span></span> derived from our detected S-band sources. The luminosities were scaled to 1.4 GHz and averaged over all eight\u00a0lensing models. The uncertainties in black are shown at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn176.gif\" alt=\"$1\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\sigma</script></span></span> and include the Poisson errors and scatter between the eight\u00a0different lensing models. For reference, the red error bars only show the scatter (standard deviation) in the luminosity function from the eight\u00a0different lensing models. Results from Best et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib6\">2005</a>) for a <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn177.gif\" alt=\"$z\\lt 0.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\lt 0.3</script></span></span> sample are also shown. The Best et al. sample is divided into SF galaxies and AGNs.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522115f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadFigure/figure/apj522115f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522115f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522115f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Another uncertainty for the derived luminosity function is related to cosmic variance. Based on the computed volume, we probe for the three luminosity bins and the number of objects in each bin, we compute the cosmic variance using Trenti &amp; Stiavelli (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib59\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib59\">2008</a>). From this computation, we find that cosmic variance introduces an extra uncertainty between 22% and 30%. Note, however, that this is a factor of a few smaller the Poisson errors and scatter due to the different lensing models.</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522115f4\">4</a> we also plot the low-redshift (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn178.gif\" alt=\"$z\\lt 0.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\lt 0.3</script></span></span>) luminosity function derived by Best et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib6\">2005</a>). Although the uncertainties in our luminosity function are substantial, we find evidence for an increase in the number density of sources of a factor between 4 and 10 compared to the Best et al. low-redshift sample.</p><p>With a larger sample (for example, including all six Frontier Fields clusters), it should become possible to map out the luminosity function more accurately, as the Poisson errors can be reduced by a factor of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn179.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim \\sqrt{6}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim \\sqrt{6}</script></span></span>. Surveys covering a larger area will be needed to map out the high-luminosity end. These surveys can be shallower and do not require the extra amplification by lensing. A major limitation of the precision that can be achieved for the faint\u00a0end of the luminosity function, which can only be accessed with the power of lensing, is the accuracy of the lensing models. This highlights the importance of further improving the precision of the Frontier Fields lensing models (see also Limousin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib40\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib40\">2015</a>).</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522115s4\" name=\"apj522115s4\">4.\u00a0DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In our <em>JVLA</em> radio images of MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745, we discovered seven\u00a0lensed sources with expected amplification factors larger than 2. This makes MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745 the cluster with the largest number of known lensed radio sources. Two of these radio sources are also detected in our <em>Chandra</em> X-ray image. To our knowledge, only two other lensed X-ray sources behind a galaxy cluster are known (Abell 370;\u00a0Bautz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib2\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib2\">2000</a>). All of the lensed sources (with amplification factors <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn180.gif\" alt=\"$\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gt 2</script></span></span>) are located at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn181.gif\" alt=\"$1\\lesssim z\\lesssim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\lesssim z\\lesssim 2</script></span></span> and most seem to be star-forming galaxies with SFR of\u00a0~10\u201350 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn182.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> yr<sup>\u22121</sup> based on their radio continuum fluxes. Our search for lensed radio sources is different from previous radio studies performed by, e.g., Smail et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib58\">1997</a>), Garrett et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib28\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib28\">2005</a>), Ivison et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib30\">2010a</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib31\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib31\">2010b</a>), and Berciano Alba et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib5\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib5\">2010</a>), which targeted previously known lensed submillimeter galaxies that have SFR ~ 10<sup>2</sup>\u201310<sup>3</sup>\u00a0<em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The two lensed sources that are also detected in our <em>Chandra</em> image have 2\u201310 keV X-ray luminosities of ~10<sup>43\u201344</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>. We therefore classify these sources as AGNs (e.g., Bauer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib1\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib1\">2004</a>).</p><p>From the derived luminosity function,\u00a0we find evidence for an increase in the number density of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn183.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.0</script></span></span> radio sources compared to the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn184.gif\" alt=\"$z\\lt 0.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\lt 0.3</script></span></span> sample from Best et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib6\">2005</a>). The increase is expected given the cosmic evolution of AGNs and SF galaxies between these two redshift ranges (e.g., Best et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib7\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib7\">2014</a>; Madau &amp; Dickinson <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib43\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib43\">2014</a>). Besides the Poisson errors, we find that the scatter between the available lensing models contributes significantly to the uncertainty in our derived luminosity function.</p><p>From our <em>JVLA</em> observations, we conclude that, as expected, lensing by massive (merging) clusters enables studying star-forming galaxies at moderate to high redshifts, with the advantage of not being affected by extinction. Some of these radio sources have flux densities that are below the detection limits of typical radio observations without the amplification by lensing. In the case of MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745, our highest amplification factor is about\u00a09. To detect a source with a similar signal-to-noise ratio in the S-band, without the lensing amplification, would have required about <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn185.gif\" alt=\"$10\\times {8}^{2}\\approx 600\\;{\\rm{hr}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">10\\times {8}^{2}\\approx 600\\;{\\rm{hr}}</script></span></span> of <em>JVLA</em> integration time. Practically, this means that the Square Kilometre Array (SKA) would be the only instrument that could achieve such a detection without the help of lensing. This example is similar to the lensed radio source found by Jackson (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib32\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib32\">2011</a>). Radio observations also nicely complement far-infrared and submillimeter observations that can detect strongly star-forming galaxies behind clusters (e.g., Egami et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib24\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib24\">2010</a>; Rawle et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib55\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib55\">2015</a>).</p><p>Besides the amplification of the integrated flux density, the lensing magnification offers a chance to study these lensed sources at high spatial resolution. In the case of MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745, all lensed radio sources are not or only slightly resolved at the current <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn186.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 1^{\\prime\\prime} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 1^{\\prime\\prime}</script></span></span> resolution. A larger sample of lensing clusters is needed to increase the chances of finding a rare bright\u00a0and more highly magnified source\u00a0that would allow a detailed spatially resolved study. Based on our MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745 result, for a massive lensing cluster (for example, from the CLASH sample), we expect to detect about a handful of lensed radio sources with a pointed ~10\u00a0hr <em>JVLA</em> observation.</p><p>Detection of background lensed X-ray sources suffer from the increased X-ray background from the cluster's ICM, in particular in regions of high magnification (see Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522115f3\">3</a>). This makes X-ray observations of lensed sources comparatively less efficient than optical or radio observations. In principle, by choosing a harder energy band (i.e., 2\u201310 keV), the contrast between a typical AGN and the ICM emission can be increased. However, for massive lensing clusters, this does not work so well because they are generally quite hot (~5\u201310 keV), producing significant ICM emission in the hard X-ray band. In addition, the number density of X-ray sources on the sky that could potentially be lensed by a cluster and detected with current instruments with reasonable exposure times is typically lower than that of radio observations and thus decreases the chance of finding an object at high magnification (e.g., Brunner et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib13\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib13\">2008</a>; Condon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522115bib16\" id=\"fnref-apj522115bib16\">2012</a>). Extrapolating from our MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745 result, we expect to find of the order of one lensed X-ray object (amplification <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn187.gif\" alt=\"$\\gtrsim \\;2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gtrsim \\;2</script></span></span>) per massive lensing cluster for a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn188.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim {10}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim {10}^{2}</script></span></span> ks <em>Chandra</em> observation.</p></div>\n<div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We\u00a0thank the anonymous referee for useful comments. We thank Megan Gralla for a discussion on the lensed radio sources. The National Radio Astronomy Observatory is a facility of the National Science Foundation operated under cooperative agreement by Associated Universities, Inc. Support for this work was provided by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration through <em>Chandra</em> Award Number GO4-15129X issued by the <em>Chandra</em> X-ray Observatory Center, which is operated by the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory for and on behalf of the National Aeronautics Space Administration under contract NAS8-03060.</p><p>R.J.W. is supported by NASA through the Einstein Postdoctoral grant number PF2-130104 awarded by the <em>Chandra</em> X-ray Center, which is operated by the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory for NASA under contract NAS8-03060. G.A.O. acknowledges support by NASA through a Hubble Fellowship grant HST-HF2-51345.001-A awarded by the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Incorporated, under NASA contract NAS5-26555. M.B. acknowledges support by the research group FOR 1254 funded by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft: \"Magnetization of interstellar and intergalactic media: the prospects of low-frequency radio observations.\" W.R.F., C.J., and F.A.-S. acknowledge support from the Smithsonian Institution. F.A.-S. acknowledges support from <em>Chandra</em> grant GO3-14131X. A.Z. is supported by NASA through Hubble Fellowship grant HST-HF2-51334.001-A awarded by STScI. This research was performed while T.M. held a National Research Council Research Associateship Award at the Naval Research Laboratory (NRL). Basic research in radio astronomy at NRL by T.M. and T.E.C. is supported by 6.1 Base funding. M.D. acknowledges the support of STScI grant 12065.007-A. P.E.J.N. was partially supported by NASA contract NAS8-03060. E.R. acknowledges a Visiting Scientist Fellowship of the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, and the hospitality of the Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge. Part of this work performed under the auspices of the U.S. DOE by LLNL under Contract DE-AC52-07NA27344.</p><p>Part of the reported results are based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em>, obtained from the Data Archive at the Space Telescope Science Institute. STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. This work utilizes gravitational lensing models produced by PIs Brada\u010d Ebeling, Merten &amp; Zitrin, Sharon, and Williams funded as part of the <em>HST</em> Frontier Fields program conducted by STScI. The lens models were obtained from the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST). This research has made use of the NASA/IPAC Infrared Science Archive, which is operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under contract with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration</p><p><em>Facilities:</em> VLA - Very Large Array, CXO - Chandra X-ray Observatory satellite, <em>HST</em> - Hubble Space Telescope satellite.</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522115app1\" name=\"apj522115app1\">APPENDIX: COMPACT SOURCES: CLUSTER AND FOREGROUND OBJECTS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t5\">5</a> we list the properties of all the radio and X-ray sources that are cluster members, foreground objects, or sources with uncertain redshifts (so that we could not determine whether or not\u00a0they are lensed). We also provide <em>HST</em> color postage stamp images around these radio sources in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522115f5\">5</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522115f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522115f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115f5a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115f5a_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522115f5a\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadFigure/figure/apj522115f5a\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522115f5a\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522115f5a\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115f5b_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0<em>HST</em> F435, F606W, and F814W postage stamp color images around the compact radio sources in the MACS\u00a0J0717.3745 field. The sources in this panel are cluster members, foreground objects, or sources with uncertain redshifts (so that we could not determine whether or not\u00a0they are lensed). Postage stamp images for the lensed sources are shown in Figure <a href=\"#apj522115f2\">2</a>. The red radio contours are from the 2\u20134 GHz S-band image and drawn at levels <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn189.gif\" alt=\"$\\sqrt{([1,2,4,\\ldots ])}\\times 3{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sqrt{([1,2,4,\\ldots ])}\\times 3{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}</script></span></span>, with <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn190.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}=1.8$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}=1.8</script></span></span> <em>\u03bc</em>Jy beam<sup>\u22121</sup>. The beam size is indicated in the bottom left corner. We draw white radio contours for some images to aid visibility (in case the area was not covered by all the <em>HST</em> filters). For sources without an S-band detection, we overlay contours from the C-band image (if detected there) or L-band image. We use contours from the combined L-, S-, and C-band images if the source is not detected in any of the three individual band images. The values for <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/817/2/98/Full/apj522115ieqn191.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{{\\rm{rms}}}</script></span></span> for the L- and C-band images are listed in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522115t2\">2</a>. Note that for source S20 there is a very faint CLASH counterpart located precisely at the radio position.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522115f5b\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadFigure/figure/apj522115f5b\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522115f5b\" href=\"/0004-637X/817/2/98/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522115f5b\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<h2 id=\"footnotes\">Footnotes</h2>\n\t\t<div data-mobile-collapse=\"\">\n\t\t\t<ul class=\"clear-list wd-content-footnotes\">\n\t\t\t\t<li I have amended it to turn of JS on all IE browsers less than 10.\n\t\tThis is due to a function in the iop.jquery.toolbar line 35/36. Uses .remove which is not native js supported in IE9 or lower */\n\t\t/*if('querySelector' in document\n\t\t&& 'localStorage' in window\n\t\t&& 'addEventListener' in window)*/\n\t\t\n\t\t/* This is the updated selector, taken from: https://justmarkup.com/log/2015/02/26/cut-the-mustard-revisited/ */\n\t\tif('visibilityState' in document) {\n\t\t\n\t\t/*! loadJS: load a JS. We are loading this command straight away, before the body loads, so that IF a user has JS enabled, their show hide panels will automatically be closed. */\n\t\t/* If this isn't here, then these panels appear open while the page is loading, then when the js loads at the bottom of the page, they are shut. So the users sees open content, then hidden after a second or 2 when the js is loaded. class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">THE DISCOVERY OF LENSED RADIO AND X-RAY SOURCES BEHIND THE FRONTIER FIELDS CLUSTER MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745 WITH THE JVLA AND <I>CHANDRA</I></h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">R.
